Graphical abstract The production of carbonates from carbon dioxide and epoxides is an atom-economical, scalable and industrially relevant reaction, highlighting the use of carbon dioxide as a sustainable source of carbon. Following a brief introduction on cyclic carbonates and their applications, the use of ionic liquids (ILs) as organocatalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides is analysed. Additionally, examples of one-pot processes starting from alkenes or diols that may be used to produce carbonates are described (as these reactions are less developed the scope of the catalysts is not limited to IL catalysts). These alternatives are of special interest as simple alkenes and diols may be derived from biomass, leading to products derived entirely from renewable resources. Keywords Sustainable chemistry Carbon dioxide Ionic liquids Catalysis 1 Introduction In recent years carbon capture and storage (CCS) has become a highly important topic, due to the extremely high volumes of CO2 (about 30 GTs) produced each year [1], leading to climate change [2]. The CO2 concentration in the atmosphere has dramatically increased over the past decades, reaching an alarming 400ppm in 2015 [3]. In addition to CCS technologies, the concept of CO2 utilization is currently receiving increasing attention. In this context, CO2 is considered as a reagent rather than a waste product. The catalytic reduction of CO2 to formates and formic acid [4], methanol [5–7] and methane [8,9] is important for fuel purposes, representing a way of storing energy in chemical bonds [10–12]. Currently, the synthesis of these simple fuel molecules is only economically viable when combined with abundant (free) renewable energy sources. In addition, CO2 has been used as a C1 building block for methylation [13] or formylation [14] reactions with amines and there is a growing number of reactions that incorporate CO2 into more complex organic products [15–17]. One of the simplest ways of using CO2 involves chemical fixation through cycloaddition with epoxides to afford cyclic carbonates (Scheme 1 ) [18]. This reaction has been intensely investigated in recent years and several excellent reviews focus on different aspects of the topic [19–21]. The reaction is of industrial importance as some cyclic carbonates are used on a large scale. Consequently, many different types of catalysts have been developed for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides (the CCE reaction) such as alkali metals [22], transition metal [23,24], metal oxides [25,26], metal–organic frameworks [27] and other catalysts [28]. Herein, we discuss the importance of cyclic carbonates, their synthesis from CO2 and applications. We then discuss the mechanism of the CCE reaction catalysed by ion pairs, an important class of organocatalysts [29,30], and summarize the main ammonium, imidazolium and other ionic/IL organocatalysts. Systematic approaches used to improve catalyst performance by tailoring the cation and anion and developing solid catalysts to enhance product separation and catalyst reuse are highlighted. Finally, we illustrate how alternative starting materials to epoxides can be used, some of which can be derived from renewable sources. 2 Properties and applications of cyclic carbonates Five-membered cyclic carbonates (Fig. 1 ) have many diverse applications [31] and are produced industrially on multiton scales [32]. Small cyclic carbonates (EC, PC) may be prepared from the cycloaddition of CO2 with the corresponding epoxide (Scheme 1), typically using alkylammonium halide catalysts [33]. Other routes for carbonate production tend to be less attractive because they require the use of toxic reagents such as phosgene [34]. Ethylene carbonate (EC) and propylene carbonate (PC) are widely used as solvents [35], are used in biomass liquefaction [36], and may be converted to dimethyl carbonate which is a fuel additive [33] and methylating agent [37]. EC and PC are also used in lithium batteries [38], and PC is found in cosmetics products as it is non-toxic [39]. Glycerol carbonate (GC) can be obtained from glycerol (a bio-based product) [40], and is used as a solvent [41], in cosmetics [42] and in batteries [43]. Styrene carbonate (SC) and bicyclic cyclohexene carbonate (CC) can be converted to polycarbonates and subsequently to polyurethanes [44]. Recently, Bayer announced an industrial process for polycarbonate synthesis incorporating 20% CO2 for the production of polyurethanes [45], which have many applications as materials [46]. 3 Mechanism of the CCE reaction The mechanism of the CCE reaction catalysed by salts is depicted in Scheme 2 . In the first step the epoxide (a in the scheme) is opened via nucleophilic attack of the anion of the catalytic ion pair (step i ). Consequently, strong nucleophiles such as halide ions are often used for this reaction [47]. This ring opening step is facilitated if the catalyst is able to further activate the oxygen of the three membered ring, for example by H-bonding, typically with an alcohol functional group tethered to the cation as shown in the scheme (intermediate b) [48]. The obtained alkoxide is stabilized by the cation in order to facilitate the insertion of CO2 (species c) which takes place in the next step (i.e. step ii ). This prerequisite rationalizes why simple salts such as NaCl are inefficient catalysts for the CCE reaction unless they are strongly solvated and associated with an organic solvent such as N-methylpyrrolidine [22]. With imidazolium salts the alkoxide can potentially deprotonate the acidic C2 proton to generate the corresponding N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC). However, it has been demonstrated that this reaction does not appear to take place when the C2 proton is substituted by a methyl group, i.e. the reaction rates of the two imidazolium salts are essentially the same [49]. After insertion of CO2 a 5-membered ring is obtained by elimination of the anion of the ion pair, via a SN2-type mechanism (Scheme 3 , step iii ). Thus, the anion should be both a good nucleophile and a good leaving group, whereas the cation should provide favourable interactions to stabilize the intermediates [50]. In such a process, the interactions between the anion and cation in the catalyst are critical and should be optimized to maximize the catalytic process. Several computational studies have been performed that provide further mechanistic insights into the reaction. It has been shown that there is a difference of >20kcal/mol in the rate-determining step in the presence or absence of a catalyst [51], and that the rate-determining step comprises the ring-opening of the epoxide. These predictions were subsequently confirmed using ammonium salt catalysts in the DFT simulation [52]. 4 IL catalysts ILs are defined as salts that melt at 100°C or less [53]. Many classes of ILs have been reported and many have been used to catalyse the CCE reaction, including ILs based on imidazolium [54], ammonium [55], phosphonium and pyridinium [56] salts. A wide range of anions have also been explored with halides generally leading to best activities [57]. It should be noted that in other types of reactions ILs have been designed to improve catalytic processes [58,59]. Moreover, the emergence of the so-called polymeric ILs [60] and supported ILs [61] has further enhanced IL-based reactions with respect to reaction processing. These polymeric ILs have only some properties reminiscent of ILs, e.g. their melting points tend to be high and are not in the range of ILs. In this aspect, these materials are best referred to as “ionic polymers” rather than polymeric ionic liquids although they are derived from ILs. Although ILs are considered green alternatives to volatile organic solvents, primarily due to their low vapour pressure [62] and high stability [63], it should be noted that some ILs are unstable [64] and some are not readily biodegradable [65,66]. 4.1 Ammonium-based ILs Certain ammonium-based salts may be classified as ILs (examples are given in Fig. 2 ) and have been used to catalyse the CCE reaction. These salts are usually prepared from tertiary amines by reaction with appropriate alkyl halides and, when necessary, the anion can be exchanged by reaction with a suitable acid or Group 1 metal salt [67], although complete removal of halide impurity can be challenging [68]. It would appear that the first examples of a metal-free catalyst for the CCE reaction employed ammonium salts [33]. For example, tetrabutylammonium chloride catalyses the formation of PC under relatively mild conditions [69], and a mixture of tetrabutylammonium bromide and iodide (TBAB (1) and TBAI) may also be used to catalyse the reaction [55]. Various studies were undertaken to optimize the ion pairs employed in the CCE reaction, which support the mechanism described above. Ammonium salts with short alkyl chains are less efficient than longer chain alkyl ammonium salts, and the reactivity of the catalyst also decreases when fluoride is used as the counter anion [70]. As mentioned above, a cation that stabilizes the alkoxide intermediate via H-bonding could potentially enhance the activity of the catalyst and, for this reason, hydroxyl-functionalized ammonium salts emerged as potent catalysts for the CCE reaction. The effect of hydroxyl functionalized ammonium salts was studied with the highest activities obtained when three hydroxyl groups are present (Fig. 2, 3). Interestingly, under the experimental conditions, the authors showed that tetrahydroxyethyl ammonium salts provided lower activities [71]. Microreactor technology in combination with 2 was used to produce PC in 99% yield under 35 bars of CO2 at a residence time of only 14s [72]. Other ways to improve the processing properties of quaternary ammonium salt catalysts involve grafting the cation onto polystyrene [73] or polyethylene glycol supports [74] (Fig. 2, 4–5), providing solid catalysts that are easily recovered and reused. Quaternary ammonium salts were also attached covalently to carbon nanotubes, but the resulting catalyst is significantly less active than the polystyrene and polyethylene glycol supported systems [75]. The acidic C2 proton is not essential for catalytic activity [49], as the other two ring protons are able to form hydrogen bonds [76]. Routes to prepare imidazolium salts are very well documented and described throughout the literature [77]. Simple ILs can be prepared from 1-methylimidazole as the N-atom is nucleophilic and readily reacts with suitable organohalides to generate an imidazolium salt (1-methylimidazole is obtained from the Radziszewski reaction) [78]. Sodium imidazolide may be used as a precursor to generate compounds with two different substituents onto the imidazolium ring [79]. Reactions are often conducted in the absence of solvent, but care should be taken as the reaction is exothermic [80], the viscosity can be high [81] and the resulting IL may be very hygroscopic [82]. Following the first report of CCE reactions catalysed by imidazolium salts in 2001 [83], a plethora of related catalysts has been reported. Initially, the 1-methyl-3-butylimidazolium cation ([bmim]+) was evaluated for catalytic activity with various anions (Fig. 3 , 1). With BF4 −, a yield of 90.3% of PC was obtained after 6h at 110°C under 25bars of pressure. In more recent reports it has been shown that BF4 − salts are less active than Cl− salts. Similar to that observed for ammonium salts, the introduction of a hydroxyl group in 9 enhances catalytic activity, with yields of PO of 99% obtained under 20bars of CO2 at 125°C in 1h [48]. If the hydroxyl group is placed at the C2 position of the ring (Fig. 3, 12) the activity of the resulting catalyst is very similar [84]. A series of Brønsted acidic imidazolium salts (Fig. 3, 10–11) are efficient CCE catalysts [85], with the catalytic activity correlated with the pKa of the acidic moiety attached to the imidazolium ring. Presumably, the acidic proton facilitates ring-opening of the epoxide [86]. Several other carboxylic acid functionalized ILs were reported and show comparable activities [87,88]. A dicationic imidazolium salt (Fig. 3, 14) with a hydroxyl group operates under relative mild conditions (70°C and 4 bars of CO2) albeit at high catalyst loadings (5mol%) and long reaction times, thus making direct comparisons difficult. However, under the optimized conditions, PC is obtained in 95% yield, whereas 9 affords PC in 32% under the same conditions [89]. Longer alkyl chain imidazolium salts such as 7 show enhanced activities compared to the short chain ILs [90]. These results are consistent with the ammonium salts where longer alkyl chains also gave higher yields. A series of amino-functionalized imidazolium salts (Fig. 3, 13) were evaluated in the CCE reaction [91], with the best amine-functionalized IL yielding PC in 94% compared to 53% in [emim]Br under the same conditions. Simple protic ILs such as 8, in which the H-donor is directly attached to the imidazolium ring, were also used to catalyse the CCE reaction in high yield [92]. As in the case of ammonium salts, efforts have been made to heterogenize imidazolium salts, and several approaches were studied. Heterogeneous catalysts incorporating a hydroxyl-functionalized imidazolium salt were prepared via copolymerisation of vinyl-functionalized imidazoliums with divinylbenzene (Fig. 4 , 21) [93,94]. In a slightly different approach imidazolium salts have been anchored to a polystyrene resin [95]. The catalyst also incorporates a diol unit (Fig. 4, 16), which is able to form favourable interactions with reaction intermediates, leading to high catalytic activities. Other supports used to immobilize imidazolium cations include cross-linked polymers (Fig. 4, 15) [96], functionalized ferromagnetic beads [97], and functionalized chitosan (Fig. 4, 22) [98], and other biopolymers [99]. Since chitosan is the second most abundant bio-polymer after cellulose [100], and possesses several hydroxyl groups, it is ideal for this application. Cross-linked polymers obtained from an imidazolium salt with two styrene groups (Fig. 4, 20) [60] or the reaction of vinyl imidazolium with divinylbenzene [101], or with acrylates [102], have been evaluated in CCE reactions, as have imidazolium salts grafted on different types of silica (Fig. 4, 17) [103,104]. In these latter types of materials the imidazolium cations are easily functionalized (Fig. 4, 18) [105]. Furthermore, a supported dicationic species with a carboxylic acid functional group was synthesised and its catalytic activity evaluated (Fig. 4, 19) [106]. All the aforementioned heterogeneous systems are reasonably good catalysts for the CCE reaction, with the main advantage over simple ILs corresponding to more facile product recovery and catalyst recycling. While DBU is essentially inactive, [DBUH]Cl affords PC in 97% yield at 140°C, 10bars of CO2 after 2h with catalyst loading of 1mol%. In comparison [bmim]Br affords only 54% and [omim]Br 85% under the same conditions. Somewhat more elaborate tricationic species (Fig. 5 , 24) containing pyridinium and pyrrolidinium cations have also been reported to catalyse the CCE reaction in the presence of 2wt% water [56]. Interestingly, while most reports make efforts to exclude water from the experimental set-up, with this catalyst it was necessary to add 2wt% water to give an active catalyst solution. Related pyridinium salts were evaluated using computational methods, indicating that most functional groups attached on the nitrogen of the pyridine would not enhance the catalytic activity, with the exception of carboxylic acids [108]. In contrast to imidazolium and ammonium salts, hydroxyl functional groups on a pyridinium salt are expected to lower the catalytic potential of the salt, suggesting that the mechanism of the CCE reaction catalysed by pyridinium ions is slightly different compared to the mechanism with imidazolium salts. Triazolium salts are structurally related to imidazolium salts, but exhibit vastly different reactivities. A triazolium IL grafted onto a series of SBA-15 molecular sieves (Fig. 5, 25) led to only moderately active catalysts, even though the triazolium was functionalized with a hydroxyl functional group [109]. Choline chloride (Fig. 5, 26) combined with urea was also used to catalyse the CCE reaction [110]. When mixed, these two reagents form a deep eutectic solvent [111], and the IL mixture could be incorporated in molecular sieves which allows easy recycling. Under optimized conditions PC is formed in 99% yield after 5h at 110°C with a 1mol% catalyst loading, whereas when choline chloride was used alone PC was obtained in only 85% yield, showing that the formation of the deep eutectic solvent also provided favourable interactions for the CCE reaction. ILs derived from natural amino acids (Fig. 5, 27) afford catalysts with activities comparable to 9 [112]. Guanidinium-based ILs (Fig. 5, 28) are highly active catalysts affording PC in 95% yield under conditions in which 9 affords PC in 58% yield [113], presumably with the basicity of the guanidinium being responsible for the high activity. Phosphonium-type ILs have also been evaluated in the CCE reaction and the simple salt 29 is a potent catalyst when used in combination with water and, in this system, the water was proposed to facilitate opening of the epoxy ring [47]. Functionalized phosphonium salts have also been evaluated, with hydroxyl and carboxyl derivatives showing excellent activities (Fig. 5, 30–31) [114]. Compared to triphenylphosphonium salts 30 and 31, less sterically hindered tributylphosphonium salts were also evaluated as bifunctional catalysts, demonstrating the importance of dual activation in the CCE reaction [115,116]. Halide-free phosphonium salts were evaluated in the CCE reaction, but the yields are modest [117]. Similar to the ammonium and imidazolium salts, phosphonium-based ILs have also been anchored to polymer supports by reaction of the suitable phosphine with chloromethylpolystyrene [118]. A hybrid organic–inorganic material comprising a phosphonium salt grafted onto silica was also shown to be an efficient and recyclable catalyst (Fig. 5, 32–33) [119]. Both these heterogeneous phosphonium salts show good activities, but comparisons with a simple salt such as 1 or 9 were not reported. A more unique catalyst comprises a dicationic species with both the imidazolium and phosphonium units (Fig. 5, 34), subsequently grafted onto a poly(divinylbenzene). The dicationic species yielded 95% PC after 4h reaction at 130°C and 25bars of CO2 with a catalyst loading of 0.38mol%. The [bmim]Br salt anchored onto the same polymer affords PC in only 75% under similar reaction conditions. The dual catalyst is more effective than both the imidazolium and phosphonium salts used separately [120], possible due to simultaneous interactions of the substrates with both the imidazolium and phosphonium units. Note that the conditions employed vary making direct comparisons problematic. 5 Variations of the CCE reaction Carbonates can also be obtained directly from alkenes in the presence of CO2, an oxidant, and a catalyst (Scheme 3) [121]. This reaction may be catalysed by metal oxides in the presence of oxygen although the selectivity towards the carbonate is relatively poor due to the competitive oxidation of styrene to benzaldehyde [122]. More recently, a system based on gold nanoparticles that generate SC from styrene with improved selectivity towards the target product has been reported [123]. In this process tert-butylhydroperoxide (TBHP) is used as the oxidant. A system, comprising TBAB and TBHP, progresses in a different manner [124], with the TBHP reacting with the bromide anion of TBAB to afford an OBr− species, which subsequently reacts with water and styrene to afford bromohydrin, and finally, after CO2 insertion, eliminates Br− to form SC (Scheme 4 ). ILs combined with urea, hydrogen peroxide and methyltrioxorhenium catalyse the one-pot synthesis of styrene to SC, but only in low yields [125]. Alternatively, the reaction takes place using aqueous TBHP as the oxidant in [bmim]Br. Under 5 bars of CO2 at 150°C a high conversion of styrene was observed, but the selectivity towards the target product was moderate [50]. Another metal-free approach using N-bromosuccinimide (NBS) and DBU in water under relatively mild conditions has been reported that affords SC in 89% yield [126]. Here, the alkene is initially transformed into the corresponding bromohydrin prior to the DBU catalysed CCE reaction. Interestingly, this intermediate obtained in situ is the same intermediate discussed in the CCE reaction and, therefore, an alternative approach would be to transform the alkene into an intermediate present in the CCE reaction. Using CO2 in the synthesis of carbonates is clearly advantageous from an environmental perspective; however, the remainder of the molecule is still derived from petrochemical sources. The direct transformation of alkenes to carbonates would be considerably more sustainable if the alkene was also obtained from a renewable source. The simplest alkene, ethylene, is currently produced by hydrocarbon-cracking, but can also be obtained by dehydration of ethanol in the presence of a suitable catalyst [127]. As bioethanol is widely available [128], and consequently bioethylene, it may be envisaged that EC could be produced from entirely renewable substrates, i.e. CO2, oxygen and bioethylene, as proposed in Scheme 5 . In the examples discussed above concerning the direct transformation of alkenes to carbonates the oxidant used is usually a peroxide, and, in an ideal case, the oxidant should come from the oxygen present in air. Diols represent another potential renewable starting material for the production of carbonates using CO2. Common diols such as ethylene glycol (EG) or propylene glycol (PG) are abundant, cheap and generally less toxic than their epoxide analogues and their physical properties make them easy to handle [129]. Moreover, diols, and more generally polyols, may be derived from biomass [130], although EG is currently produced from the hydrolysis of ethylene oxide [131]. The application of diols as starting materials for the synthesis of carbonates has not been investigated as thoroughly as that of epoxides. Diols are less reactive than epoxides and a molecule of water is released in the transformation (Scheme 6 ). The lower reactivity of diols necessitates the use of more forcing conditions than those employed in the CCE reaction and most catalysts evaluated are based on homogeneous and heterogeneous metal-based systems. A system comprising CeO2 and 2-cyanopyridine, the latter acting as both the solvent and dehydrating agent by forming the corresponding amide, catalyses a carboxylation/hydration cascade to produce the target compound [132]. TBD or DBU in acetonitrile has been used to produce propylene carbonate from 1,2-propanediol [133]. In this reaction acetonitrile acts as a dehydrating agent to produce acetic acid and ammonia. DBU in [bmim]BF4 catalyses the transformation of several diols into cyclic and acyclic carbonates in the presence of CH2Br2 [134]. The proposed mechanism involves deprotonation of the diol by DBU, which allows CO2 to insert into the formed alkoxide. Such a process takes place because DBU forms an adduct with CO2, although the nature of the adduct is not well-defined [135]. Finally, CH2Br2 is present to generate a good leaving group for the ring-closure step (Scheme 7 ). Alternatively, the reaction is possible with a simple base catalyst (K2CO3) operating under supercritical conditions in the presence of benzonitrile, which also acts as a dehydrating agent [136]. In the examples cited above a major challenge is to trap the generated water and the mechanism by which the water is eliminated is not fully understood. 6 Outlook ILs have emerged as an important class of solvents for biphasic catalysis and as organocatalysts in their own right, although there are only a few industrial applications where they are used in catalysis [137]. However, IL-like catalysts are employed in the synthesis of cyclic carbonates and recent studies show that some new IL catalysts are considerably more active than those currently used. The use of alternative starting materials including certain diols or alkenes for the one-pot synthesis of carbonates could be an interesting alternative to epoxides, especially if they are derived from sustainable sources. Indeed, ILs are being explored in other types of reactions involving CO2 as a C1 feedstock. For example, [bmim]Cl was used as catalyst for hydroformylation of amines in the presence of silanes [138] and protic ILs based on DBU catalyse the formation of oxazolidinones from CO2 and propargylic amines [58]. These examples highlight the potential of ILs in CO2 utilization and it seems likely that industrial applications of IL catalysed processes will be developed. coredata.dc:description: The production of carbonates from carbon dioxide and epoxides is an atom-economical, scalable and industrially relevant reaction, highlighting the use of carbon dioxide as a sustainable source of carbon. Following a brief introduction on cyclic carbonates and their applications, the use of ionic liquids (ILs) as organocatalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides is analysed. Additionally, examples of one-pot processes starting from alkenes or diols that may be used to produce carbonates are described (as these reactions are less developed the scope of the catalysts is not limited to IL catalysts). These alternatives are of special interest as simple alkenes and diols may be derived from biomass, leading to products derived entirely from renewable resources.
